Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.B.1.Nd.10 - Madrean Lowland Evergreen Woodland NT (LC -- VU)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.B.1.Nd.10 - Madrean Lowland Evergreen Woodland NT (LC -- VU)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.B.1.Nd.10 - Madrean Lowland Evergreen Woodland' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.B.1.Nd Madrean & Southwest Great Plains Warm Temperate Woodland & Scrub' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Characteristic-biota.Taxon: Quercus grisea,Quercus oblongifolia,Juniperus monosperma,Pinus edulis,Arctostaphylos pungens
Quercus grisea,Quercus turbinella,Rhus trilobata,Aristida Spp.,Bouteloua curtipendula

Biotic-processes.Summary: Estas sabanas han ampliamente espaciados enebros maduros y moderada a alta cobertura de gramíneas ( > cubierta 25 % ) (1) .bosques dominados por encinares Madrenses a lo largo de una transición de baja pendiente por debajo del Bosque Madreano Montano Bajo de Pino-Roble (2). bosques formados por árboles escuamifolios (hojas en forma de escama) del género Juniperus a los que se les conoce como táscate, enebro o cedro, con una altura promedio de 8 a 15 m. (4)

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Classification-system.Classification-element: 1.B.1.Nd Madrean & Southwest Great Plains Warm Temperate Woodland & Scrub

Distribution.Summary: Bsq. Encinal madrense Sureste de Arizona y el sur de Nuevo Mexico, se extiende hacia el oeste de Texas y México(1). Sierra Madre Occidental y Sierra Madre Oriental de México (2). Suroeste de Mexico(4)
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'California coastal sage and chaparral'
WWF ecoregion 'Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre del Sur pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre de Oaxaca pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Occidental pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Oriental pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sonoran-Sinaloan transition subtropical dry forest'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Oriental and Occidental pine-oak forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.B.1.Nd.10 - Madrean Lowland Evergreen Woodland' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: None of the evaluated indicators reached the thresholds for Vulnerable for any criteria, but it almost reached the threshold for criteria and could become Vulnerable soon. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os LC -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Assessment-unit.name: Mexico

Ecosystem-subset.name: National: Mexico
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Country-level assessment of '1.B.1.Nd.10 - Madrean Lowland Evergreen Woodland' macrogroup in Mexico.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for VU was reached for criterion. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os LC -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Assessment-unit.name: United States

Ecosystem-subset.name: National: United States
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Country-level assessment of '1.B.1.Nd.10 - Madrean Lowland Evergreen Woodland' macrogroup in United States.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for CR was reached for criterion. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os EN -- CR.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for CR for subcriterion A2b. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A2b could be in the range of CR -- EN.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.B.1.Nd.15 - Comanchian Forest & Woodland CR (VU -- CR)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.B.1.Nd.15 - Comanchian Forest & Woodland CR (VU -- CR)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.B.1.Nd.15 - Comanchian Forest & Woodland' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.B.1.Nd Madrean & Southwest Great Plains Warm Temperate Woodland & Scrub' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Classification-system.Classification-element: 1.B.1.Nd Madrean & Southwest Great Plains Warm Temperate Woodland & Scrub

Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Central and Southern mixed grasslands'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.B.1.Nd.15 - Comanchian Forest & Woodland' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for CR was reached for criterion. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os VU -- CR.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: This subcriterion was evaluated, but the uncertainty in the estimates of recent changes in woodland cover was too high to reliable assign a category.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for CR for subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of VU -- CR.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.
